formula:
Expressed as a single equation:

eGFRcr = 142 x min(Scr/κ, 1)^α x max(Scr/κ, 1)^-1.200 x 0.9938^Age x 1.012 [if female]

where:
Scr = standardized serum creatinine in mg/dL
κ = 0.7 (females) or 0.9 (males)
α = -0.241 (female) or -0.302 (male)
min(Scr/κ, 1) is the minimum of Scr/κ or 1.0
max(Scr/κ, 1) is the maximum of Scr/κ or 1.0

title: Bedside Schwartz
usage: Used to estimate eGFR in children.
formula: eGFR = (0.413 × Height in cm) / Serum Creatinine in mg/dL

definition: eGFR is an estimate of how well your kidneys are filtering blood.
It measures the rate at which your kidneys remove waste and excess fluid, using blood creatinine levels, age, sex, and sometimes race.
Units: milliliters per minute per 1.73 m² of body surface area (mL/min/1.73 m²).
importance: Monitors progression of chronic kidney disease (CKD).
Guides medication dosing and treatment decisions.
calculation_methods:
CKD-EPI (2021): 
Preferred method using serum creatinine, age, and sex. 
More accurate at higher kidney function.
MDRD: Older method, less accurate in normal or near-normal kidney function.

Bedside Schwartz: Used for children. 
Uses height and serum creatinine.
normal_ranges:
>= 90: Normal

60-89: Mildly decreased

45-59: Mild to moderate decrease

30-44: Moderate to severe decrease

15-29: Severe decrease

< 15: Kidney failure
factors_affecting_eGFR:
Serum creatinine levels (affected by muscle mass, diet, medications)

Age (eGFR declines with age)

Sex (women generally have lower creatinine)

Race (previous equations included race; new CKD-EPI does not require it)

Hydration status and lab variability
limitations:
eGFR is an estimate, not a precise measurement

May be inaccurate in very muscular or frail people, pregnancy, or rapid kidney function changes

Should always be interpreted alongside clinical context and other lab results
